observations.title: Recovery Board Not Shown in Primary Details - Addendum 2 Critical
observations.insight: The 5/8" GP Dens Deck recovery board required by Addendum 2 is ESSENTIAL for warranty compliance but does NOT appear in the primary architectural detail A2.3 for Roof Type R1. This creates a high risk that estimators working only from the main drawing set will miss this significant cost item. The addendum explicitly states this is required 'to become eligible for the requested warranty.'
suggested_actions: FLAG this as a critical review item for all estimators and subcontractors
Verify square footage of all R1 roof areas from plan A1.2
Contact recovery board manufacturer to confirm attachment method and warranty compliance
Consider this a high-risk item for subcontractor omissions and clarify explicitly in bid invitations

observations.title: Multi-Trade Rooftop Work Sequencing is Complex and Weather-Dependent
observations.insight: The project requires demolishing 6 RTUs and associated equipment, removing existing roofing, installing new roofing system, installing new curbs, setting new RTUs, and making final connections - all on an occupied building in Alaska. The sequencing must maintain a weather-tight envelope throughout. Temporary protection, phasing, and coordination between Demolition, Roofing, Mechanical, and Electrical trades is complex and weather-dependent.
suggested_actions: Develop a detailed phasing plan showing sequence of work for each RTU replacement
Include costs for temporary weather protection (tarps, enclosures) during equipment changeout
Schedule pre-bid coordination meeting with all trades to discuss sequencing
Consider weather delays and extended schedule for Alaska climate
Clarify owner's requirements for maintaining building occupancy during construction

observations.title: Unknown Existing Conditions Create Significant Pricing Risk
observations.insight: Multiple critical existing conditions are unknown: (1) condition of roof deck beneath BUR, (2) existing electrical panel layouts and available space, (3) existing gas service capacity, (4) existing ductwork condition, (5) soil conditions for drain fields. These unknowns create significant risk of cost overruns and change orders.
suggested_actions: REQUEST geotechnical report from owner for drain field excavation
REQUEST existing electrical panel schedules and room layout drawings
PERFORM pre-bid site visit to inspect electrical room, roof deck (if accessible), and mechanical equipment
INCLUDE explicit contingency allowances for: roof deck repairs (10-15%), electrical circuit modifications (10-20%), ductwork repairs (5-10%)
DOCUMENT all assumptions clearly in the bid for owner review

observations.title: Gas Service Capacity May Be Inadequate for New Equipment
observations.insight: Six new RTUs with gas heating totaling approximately 920 MBH (0.92 MMBH) of gas input are being installed. The existing gas meter and service size are not documented. Utility company coordination for meter/service upgrade is not explicitly addressed in the scope but may be required.
suggested_actions: Calculate total new gas load from RTU schedule (sum all MBH inputs)
Request existing gas service size and meter capacity from owner
Contact local gas utility to verify capacity and determine if upgrade is required
Clarify responsibility for gas service upgrade costs (owner vs. contractor)
Include allowance for meter/service modifications if scope is unclear

observations.title: Electrical Panelboard Modifications Are Extensive and High-Risk
observations.insight: The electrical scope includes replacing a main breaker (300A to 400A), replacing a feeder to Panel A, demolishing Panel X, installing new Panel D, relocating all circuits from X to D, and adding a new Panel MECH with a new feeder from the main. This is extensive work in an occupied building requiring a full facility outage. Existing panel locations and circuit conditions are unknown.
suggested_actions: Perform detailed site investigation of existing electrical room BEFORE bidding
Verify space is available for new Panel D and Panel MECH
Identify feeder routing paths and confirm conduit is reusable
Coordinate required outage duration with owner and include costs for after-hours/weekend work if needed
Include explicit allowance for unforeseen circuit modifications when relocating from Panel X to Panel D

observations.title: Additive Alternates #1 and #2 Must Be Priced Separately
observations.insight: The replacement of RTU-1 (Alternate #1) and RTU-6 (Alternate #2) must be priced separately from the base bid per the bid form. All associated work (demo, roofing, mechanical, electrical) for these two units must be broken out.
suggested_actions: Create separate cost breakdowns for all work related to RTU-1 and RTU-6
Ensure all subcontractors provide separate pricing for alternates
Review bid form (page 17 of bid package) to confirm alternate pricing format
Consider mobilization costs - are separate mobilizations required if only one alternate is accepted?

observations.title: Extensive Manual Takeoff Required - No Quantities Provided
observations.insight: The extraction correctly notes that almost all linear, area, and volume quantities must be manually taken off from the plans. This includes: all roofing areas, parapet flashings, excavation volumes, piping linear footage, and conduit runs. This represents significant estimating effort.
suggested_actions: Allocate sufficient time for detailed quantity takeoff
Use digital takeoff software if available to improve accuracy and provide backup
Verify all scales on plans before measuring
Cross-check quantities between related items (e.g., roof drain count should match rainleader pipe runs)
Request clarification from engineer for any ambiguous dimensions or areas

observations.title: Mechanical and Electrical Specifications Are Detailed but Require Careful Review
observations.insight: The mechanical specifications (M0.2) and electrical notes (E4.0) are detailed and include important requirements such as: seismic restraint calculations, TAB by independent agency, specific duct construction standards (SMACNA), and warranty requirements. These must be carefully reviewed as they impact cost.
suggested_actions: Review mechanical specifications M0.2 in detail for compliance requirements
Include cost for independent TAB agency (not just contractor self-balance)
Include cost for engineer-stamped seismic restraint calculations and shop drawings
Verify ductwork pressure class requirements (2" WC low pressure, 4" WC medium pressure)
Confirm warranty requirements are achievable with specified equipment
